p: Welcome to Conor's Favorite Recipes!
Here you will find all my favorite recipes, carefully curated for every occasion and mood. Let's start cooking!
© 2024 Conor Jeffries. All Rights Reserved.
1 cup coconut milk
1 cup wild rice
1 large butternut squash, peeled and cubed
1 lb baby carrots
1 lb green beans, trimmed
1 onion, diced
1 tbsp coarse salt
1 tsp black pepper
1 tsp lemon zest, salt to taste
1 tsp vanilla extract
1/2 cup dried cranberries
1/2 cup unsweetened almond milk (adjust for desired consistency)
1/2 tsp cinnamon, salt to taste
1/3 cup olive oil
1/4 cup fresh parsley, chopped
1/4 cup maple syrup
2 cups coconut milk
2 cups vegetable stock
2 lbs Yukon gold potatoes, peeled and cubed
2 tbsp fresh rosemary, chopped
2 tbsp fresh thyme, chopped
2 tbsp honey
2 tbsp olive oil
2 tbsp olive oil, salt to taste
2 tbsp slivered almonds
2 tsp agar-agar powder
3 cups vegetable stock
3 garlic cloves, minced
4 garlic cloves, minced
4 garlic cloves, peeled
4-5 lb prime rib
Add almonds and lemon zest before serving.
Add olive oil, almond milk, salt, and pepper to the potatoes.
Add the cubed potatoes and garlic cloves to the Instant Pot.
After cooking, remove the prime rib from the bag and pat it dry with paper towels.
Blanch green beans for 3 minutes, then sauté in olive oil.
Blend until smooth, then stir in coconut milk.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then lower the heat and simmer for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours, or until set.
Cook rice in vegetable stock.
Drain the water from the potatoes and return them to the Instant Pot.
Fresh berries or fruit compote for topping
Heat a skillet over high heat with a small amount of olive oil. Sear the prime rib on all sides for 1-2 minutes until a golden-brown crust forms.
In a saucepan, whisk together the coconut milk, maple syrup, vanilla extract, and agar-agar powder.
Let the prime rib rest for 10 minutes before slicing and serving.
Mash using a potato masher or hand mixer until smooth, adjusting almond milk for desired consistency.
Olive oil, salt, pepper, cinnamon, nutmeg
Once cooking is complete, perform a quick release of the pressure.
Place the seasoned prime rib in a vacuum-sealed bag or a resealable freezer bag using the water displacement method.
Pour in 1 cup of water and season with a pinch of salt.
Pour the mixture into ramekins or serving glasses and let cool to room temperature.
Roast at 400°F (200°C) for 25 minutes.
Roast the squash with olive oil, salt, and pepper at 400°F (200°C) for 25–30 minutes.
Rub the prime rib with a mixture of garlic, rosemary, thyme, olive oil, salt, and pepper.
Salt and pepper to taste
Sauté onion and garlic until soft. Add roasted squash, vegetable stock, and spices.
Seal the Instant Pot lid and set to "Pressure Cook" (Manual) on High for 8 minutes.
Serve topped with fresh berries or fruit compote.
Set your sous vide machine to 135°F (57°C) for medium-rare.
Stir in cranberries, parsley, olive oil, and salt.
Submerge the sealed prime rib in the water bath and cook for 6 hours.
Taste and adjust seasoning as needed. Serve warm.
Toss carrots with honey, olive oil, cinnamon, and salt.
1 1/2 pounds butternut squash, peeled, seeded, and cubed
1 medium carrot, peeled and chopped
1 medium onion, chopped
1 pork tenderloin (about 1.5 pounds)
1 pound Brussels sprouts, halved
1 tbsp lemon juice
1 tsp cinnamon
1 tsp dried rosemary
1 tsp dried thyme
1 tsp garlic powder
1 tsp onion powder
1/2 cup all-purpose flour
1/2 cup rolled oats
1/2 cup unsweetened almond milk (or any unsweetened non-dairy milk)
1/2 tsp black pepper
1/2 tsp dried thyme
1/2 tsp salt
1/3 cup coconut oil (solid but softened) or a vegan butter substitute
1/4 cup brown sugar
1/4 cup granulated sugar
1/4 tsp nutmeg
2 cloves garlic, minced
2 garlic cloves, minced
2 pounds Yukon Gold potatoes, peeled and cubed
2 tbsp balsamic glaze
2 tbsp Dijon mustard
2 tbsp olive oil
3 tbsp olive oil
4 cups peeled and sliced apples (e.g., Granny Smith or Honeycrisp)
4 cups vegetable broth
Add the butternut squash, vegetable broth, thyme, salt, and pepper. Stir to combine.
Bake for 35–40 minutes, or until the topping is golden and the apples are bubbling.
Boil the potatoes in salted water until tender, about 15–20 minutes.
Coconut cream or toasted pumpkin seeds for garnish (optional)
Drain and mash the potatoes using a potato masher or ricer.
Drizzle with balsamic glaze before serving.
In a separate bowl, mix oats, flour, and coconut oil until crumbly. Sprinkle evenly over the apples.
In a small bowl, mix garlic powder, onion powder, rosemary, thyme, salt, and pepper. Rub the spice mixture evenly over the pork.
In a small saucepan, heat olive oil, almond milk, and garlic until warmed. Stir into the potatoes.
Let rest for 5–10 minutes before slicing.
Place the tenderloin on the baking sheet and roast for 20–25 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 145°F (63°C).
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease an 8-inch square baking dish.
Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Preheat the oven to 425°F (220°C). Line a baking sheet with foil.
Roast for 20–25 minutes, flipping halfway through, until golden and crispy.
Rub the pork tenderloin with olive oil and Dijon mustard.
Salt and pepper to taste
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Secure the lid on the Instant Pot and set it to high pressure for 12 minutes. Once done, perform a quick release.
Serve hot, garnished with coconut cream or toasted pumpkin seeds if desired.
Serve warm. For a creamy touch, add a scoop of dairy-free vanilla ice cream or whipped coconut cream.
Set the Instant Pot to the sauté function and heat the olive oil. Add the onion and carrot, cooking until softened, about 5 minutes. Add garlic and sauté for 1 minute.
Toss apples with granulated sugar, brown sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, and lemon juice. Spread in the baking dish.
Toss Brussels sprouts with olive oil, salt, and pepper. Spread evenly on the baking sheet.
Use an immersion blender to puree the soup until smooth. Alternatively, transfer the soup to a blender and blend in batches.
